The red and green electric
neon inscribing the weekly
specials in the window of .the
Restaurant Oxford glows
illicitly. Its the kind of place you
can pass by a thousand times
Without ever noticing.
The atmosphere inside, Early
Depression, further confirms
Your suspicions of drabness, as
the monotony of washed out
Pink, and powder blue is broken
Only by the ridiculous radiators
gleaming down at you from the
top of the wall.
But don't be alarmed, you've
stepped into the hands of the
self-proclaimed "greatest chef in
Baltimore," John J. Pierre.
John J. Pierre, a Greek with a
henchman's name is the most
intriguing feature of the
restaurant at 3312 Greenmount
Avenue. Pierre, with his thinning
slicked back hair dirty apron,
serves as waiter, lief de cuisine,
busboy, cash register operator,
and as your friendly and
talkative host. He is able to do
all these jobs because customers
drift in very slowly and
irregularly. "But it's not the
volume of business you do that's
I mportant," says Pierre,"it's the

money you take home at the
end of the week."
Pierre is very sensitive about
the condition of his
establishment. When he took it
over a year ago he had to invest
over $1200 to whip it into
working order. But, he refuses to
do more renovating since he is
only renting the building.
"At least my place is clean,if
anyone can find caked-on dirt or
a cockroach I'll eat it," said
Pierre.
• Finest
Pierre reminisced, "At one
time I owned the finest
restaurant in Baltimore, The
Restaurant Pierre." He bought
the Baltimore restaurant
Maxim's in 1945, renamed it,
and it boasted the finest cuisine
in the area. If you ask he will
pull out his briefcase filled with
news clippings and autographed
pictures of himself with such
notables as Charles de Gaulle
and Edward G. Robinson, and
ramble on for hours.
He lost the establishment,
which was netting him $1,000 a
week, because of a rape incident
in his parking lot at the 704 N.
Howard St. location, which
eventually lead to his loss of

customers and bankrupcy.
"It was a story of going from
riches to rags," said Pierre.
But Pierre knew poverty
before when he first came to this
country from Athens in 1922.
He started his culinary career by
busing tables in the Waldorf
Astoria in New York. But he
quickly rose to the post of chief
steward on the Moore-McCormick Ocean Lines and to head
chef at the St. Regis in New
York.
Pierre, though he went to
school for only three months,
claims to know five languages
and he has taught himself
different styles of cooking.
"People don't care about the
students, but I have a great love
of learning and I would like to
see and meet more Hopkins
students," said Pierre.

does know with loving care and
provides an extra helping of
most dishes he serves. He has
established a small but
consistent clientele who know
him and come to partake of his
good food, and conversation, all
for a very moderate price.

Concert Loses Money
Despite relatively high
attendance, preliminary figures
I ndicate that Friday's
Youngbloods concert will lose
several thousand dollars.
Andrew Savitz, who
coordinated the Student Council
Sponsored concert, set the loss
figure as "at least $2,000." He
said that final expenditure totals
have not yet been compiled.
Savitz reported that 1,400
tickets were sold for the event.
2,200 tickets would have
represented a sell-out. "When I
took over control of the concert,
no more than 40 tickets had
been sold," he said. Savitz had
earlier stated that the advance
Planning of the concert was
Poorly done.
On Their Own
The Student Council, after
deciding on Nov. 1 to curtail all
cooperation with the
administration except on the
governance reform issue, elected
to run the concert on their own.
They renounced administration
support, deciding to sponsor and
Operate the concert themselves.
The Council's decision to run
the event without school
support came on the heels of the
resignation of Esta Baker,
Council VP and Social
Committee Chairman. The
resultant confusion lead many
Council members to estimate
that losses from the
Youngbloods concert would
total over $4,000. Savitz then
volunteered to run the event.
Savitz commented that the
lack of Administration support
for the concert was not a factor
in the losswhich was incurred. "I
don't think that administration
cooperation could have helped
us any," he said. Savitz had

earlier indicated that the turnout
would be a measure of student
support for SC actions to cut
administration ties.
Many Council members at the
Nov. 1 meeting were opposed to
continuing the proposed
concert, saying that the
projected loss would be greater
than the Council could afford.
"If we lose a lot of money on
this concert, it will shoot down
the social events for the rest of
the year," one member said.
Some Council members were
critical of the manner in which
Baker handled the advance
planning of the event. Some
speculated that the poor planing

of the concert was one of the
factors leading to Baker's sudden
resignation. As vice-president of
the Council, Baker was
responsible for all social events
sponsored by the SC. She
reported that her resignation was
based on "personal" reasons.
The Youngbloods reportedly
received $4,500 payment for the
performance. Gate receipts from
1,400 tickets would have
totaled under $4,000.
Additional expenses (building
rental, set-up costs) boosted the
total cost. "If we had a sell-out
crowd, we would still have lost
about $500," Savitz said.

Vector and the Charles St.

major portion of Hopkins

see undergraduates working in
special areas of science which

Economou stated they
received papers by sending

May asking them to speak with

and see if they wanted to write

Governance
The SC Governance Committee's tentative governance
proposals are a bold step forward in granting students real
policy-making power. But the narrowness of its proposed
student-faculty Central Committee and the grandiose
nature of some suggested reforms make revisions necessary
before their December 1 interim governance report is
released. The low participation so far in the committee's
meetings point to the greatest danger facing the Student
Council in winning a new governance system: lack of
student support. Faculty and administration opposition to
major changes will, of course, be intense, and unless the
Student Council'is willing to go through the hard work of
interesting students in governance reform, nothing can be
accomplished.
Right now, it seems that the Governance Committee is
headed towards an interim report that will call for a
17-member student-faculty committee with the power of
review over Homewood's academic, non-academic and
budgetary decisions. The proposed committee would best
serve the interests of both students and faculty if it
became more than a mere committee and was expanded to
a University Senate, affording a wider representation and
broader discussion of issues. This would tend to submerge
the personality differences which have plagued the Student
Council this year. And having veto power over complex
fiscal affairs is a responsibility too overwhelming for
part-time policy-makers like students and faculty. But like
the Academic Council now, a future University Senate
should be fully incorporated into the fiscal
decision-making process in an advisory capacity.
In the other key areas of Arts and Sciences concern,
though, there is no reason why a representative body for
students and faculty should not have veto power over
academic and non-academic decisions, since they will be
the ones most affected by them. A University Senate
would not supplant other important decision - making
groups on campus,such as the Academic Council, but only
make them more responsive by having their decisions
reviewed by a body with broader representation. The main
task before the Student Council now is coming up with a
realizable plan that can unite students, as well as enlisting
the support of faculty members and administrators
interested in change.

participate in them."

The blackwall tires of Campus Patrol
Car no. 1 splash through the puddles as
the white, 1971 Ford Torino and its
driver, Officer Bob Hitchcock, patrol
the roads and buildings of the Hopkins
campus.
Around the Clock
The patrol car runs 24 hours a day
and the drivers, along with the
watchmen on foot, work in three shifts:
7 am-3 pm, 3 pm-11 pm, and 11 pm-7
am. On the 11-7 shift, the five night
watchmen patrol and check all the
buildings on campus, punching the
round, black watchclocks as they go.
The driver of the car is responsible for
checking the University owned buildings
off campus and patrolling the campus
roads through the morning hours.
"Unit one, there are cars all over
the place up here by the concert."
"We'll tag 'em all. 10-4."
The Youngbloods concert has been
under way for a half-hour and the sound
of straining guitar amps drifts through
the open doors of the Athletic Center as
the patrol car passes by. Officer
Hitchcock checks the situation with the
Pinkertons on duty for the concert.
Hitchcock is sixtyish, but, talkative,

chipper and very conscientious about
his job.
At 10 pm, Unit One rolls by the
well-lit freshmen dorms and down to
the ROTC building. When the car passes
through the gates, past the gray,
wooden structure, two people can be
seen sitting against the back of the
Athletic Center passing a joint. When
they see the car they casually get up and
walk around front, as if they had
nothing to worry about. Hitchcock gets
out of the car and goes up after them,
but by the time he makes his way up
the wet, cement steps the pair is gone
and all he finds is a box of burnt
matches. Getting back in the car he
mumbles, "They had enough matches
up there to start a bonfire— I wonder
what they were doing."
"Unit one. We're going to need
extra men when this concert
breaks up."
"There are no extra men,Sam."
"Call Mr. Weinbach and ask him."
"He's probably in bed."
"O.K. Bob. 10-4."
The wind is picking up and the sky
has cleared, as if to signal the cold to
move in. The patrolmen on foot are
making their rounds and when they see
the car, they seem anxious to talk to
someone. The man checking the faculty
club said he found a door open, but that
everything else was fine. All the.
watchmen carry walkie-talkies and can

contact the patrol car at any time.
Shift Changes
At 11 pm, the car winds its way back
to the security office in Whitehead Hall
and the shift changes. Thirteen men
stand packed together in the 9' by 10'
office, exchanging radios and punching
the time clock.
After the shift changes, Officer Bill
Deese takes over the patrol car: He is
middle-aged and talks a lot about his
two sons in the Navy.
For what seems about the hundredth
time, he checks the Rodgers House,
Homewood House, and Wolman Hall.
By this time the concert has broken up
and a steady stream of cars leave the
campus. A few couples walk arm in arm
towards the dorms or their cars and the
campus begins to quiet down.
"Unit one to post one- come in
please."
"Post one here."
"Have you been Levering yet?"
"Yeah, everything's quiet."
"O.K. Donny. 10-4."
The security people check the
Levering Cafeteria often because of the
food machines, according to Deese. All
doors, except the front, are locked and
checked by the watchmen on every
round.
Bush-Whacking
Another activity of the campus patrol
is bush-whacking parkers on San Martin
Drive with the car's powerful

searchlight. Tonight the activity is
limited and Deese manages flush out
only one couple with very steamed up
windows.
"Unit one, is that you on the grass
in front of the dorms?"
"No it isn't."
"O.K. 10-4."
At 1:30 am the campus is enveloped
in silence and only a few cars can be
seen leaving through the gate in front of
the library. The cold has moved in and
the few people on Charles Street move
quickly toward the warmth of their
homes and beds. Deese is checking the
computer center in Garland Hall, the
lights shining down the sides making it
stand out under the crystal clear, starry
sky.
Lights remain on in some of the
campus buildings where the janitors are
hard at work mopping the floors and
washing the blackboards covered with
white dust.
Moving slowly around the perimeter
of campus, Deese stops to put up
barricades for the football game the
next day. He moves quickly in the cold,
wearing only a sweater. When he gets
back in the car he seems refreshed and
wide awake, despite the fact that it is
three o'clock in the morning. Moving
away from the Athletic Center the wind
blows hundreds of leaves against the
fence surrounding the practice field as
Deese begins another set of rounds.

Governance
The SC Governance Committee's tentative governance
proposals are a bold step forward in granting students real
policy-making power. But the narrowness of its proposed
student-faculty Central Committee and the grandiose
nature of some suggested reforms make revisions necessary
before their December 1 interim governance report is
released. The low participation so far in the committee's
meetings point to the greatest danger facing the Student
Council in winning a new governance system: lack of
student support. Faculty and administration opposition to
major changes will, of course, be intense, and unless the
Student Council'is willing to go through the hard work of
interesting students in governance reform, nothing can be
accomplished.
Right now, it seems that the Governance Committee is
headed towards an interim report that will call for a
17-member student-faculty committee with the power of
review over Homewood's academic, non-academic and
budgetary decisions. The proposed committee would best
serve the interests of both students and faculty if it
became more than a mere committee and was expanded to
a University Senate, affording a wider representation and
broader discussion of issues. This would tend to submerge
the personality differences which have plagued the Student
Council this year. And having veto power over complex
fiscal affairs is a responsibility too overwhelming for
part-time policy-makers like students and faculty. But like
the Academic Council now, a future University Senate
should be fully incorporated into the fiscal
decision-making process in an advisory capacity.
In the other key areas of Arts and Sciences concern,
though, there is no reason why a representative body for
students and faculty should not have veto power over
academic and non-academic decisions, since they will be
the ones most affected by them. A University Senate
would not supplant other important decision - making
groups on campus,such as the Academic Council, but only
make them more responsive by having their decisions
reviewed by a body with broader representation. The main
task before the Student Council now is coming up with a
realizable plan that can unite students, as well as enlisting
the support of faculty members and administrators
interested in change.

political parties of the United States do not
adequately represent nor reflect the social,
political or economic views of a large segment of
the American people, a new and different
political force has been organized. The
Coalition, as that force has been named, will
hold their National Convention in Dallas, Texas
November 24 through November 28, 1971.
The coalition was formed over July 4th
weedend, 1971, at a meeting in Albuquerque,
New Mexico. Participants from 25 states and
the District of Columbia were present at the
initial organizational meeting. They represented
the New Party, Peace and Freedom Party,
Human Rights Party, New Reform Party,
Independent New Mexico Party, Liberal Party,
D.C. Statehood Party and the Wisconsin
Alliance.

meeting will presented at the National
Convention. The preamble to that platform
states: "Independent political parties in many
states are now uniting to provide a national
challenge to the existing system. We are
organizing at every level to produce a new
political alternative based on grass-roots
democratic procedures, including electoral
politics, counter institutions, and non-violent,
direct action. Our goal is a new nation with
new institutions controled by the people who
participate in them."
The National Convention will also consider
possible candidates for United States President,
Vice-President, and shadow cabinet. The agenda
includes discussion of national structure. Of
that topic, the preamble says: "This new
political party recognizes the serious dangers of
polarization of our society and the alienation of
our people. We therefore dedicate ourselves to
the proposition that whatever affects one
individual must concern us all. We are more
committed to the next generation than to the

"Unit one, come in please."
"O.K., unit one here."
"Just a radio check Bob, thank
you."
"Right-o. 10-4."
The blackwall tires of Campus Patrol
Car no. 1 splash through the puddles as
the white, 1971 Ford Torino and its
driver, Officer Bob Hitchcock, patrol
the roads and buildings of the Hopkins
campus.
Around the Clock
The patrol car runs 24 hours a day
and the drivers, along with the
watchmen on foot, work in three shifts:
7 am-3 pm, 3 pm-11 pm, and 11 pm-7
am. On the 11-7 shift, the five night
watchmen patrol and check all the
buildings on campus, punching the
round, black watchclocks as they go.
The driver of the car is responsible for
checking the University owned buildings
off campus and patrolling the campus
roads through the morning hours.
"Unit one, there are cars all over
the place up here by the concert."
"We'll tag 'em all. 10-4."
The Youngbloods concert has been
under way for a half-hour and the sound
of straining guitar amps drifts through
the open doors of the Athletic Center as
the patrol car passes by. Officer
Hitchcock checks the situation with the
Pinkertons on duty for the concert.
Hitchcock is sixtyish, but, talkative,

chipper and very conscientious about
his job.
At 10 pm, Unit One rolls by the
well-lit freshmen dorms and down to
the ROTC building. When the car passes
through the gates, past the gray,
wooden structure, two people can be
seen sitting against the back of the
Athletic Center passing a joint. When
they see the car they casually get up and
walk around front, as if they had
nothing to worry about. Hitchcock gets
out of the car and goes up after them,
but by the time he makes his way up
the wet, cement steps the pair is gone
and all he finds is a box of burnt
matches. Getting back in the car he
mumbles, "They had enough matches
up there to start a bonfire— I wonder
what they were doing."
"Unit one. We're going to need
extra men when this concert
breaks up."
"There are no extra men,Sam."
"Call Mr. Weinbach and ask him."
"He's probably in bed."
"O.K. Bob. 10-4."
The wind is picking up and the sky
has cleared, as if to signal the cold to
move in. The patrolmen on foot are
making their rounds and when they see
the car, they seem anxious to talk to
someone. The man checking the faculty
club said he found a door open, but that
everything else was fine. All the.
watchmen carry walkie-talkies and can

contact the patrol car at any time.
Shift Changes
At 11 pm, the car winds its way back
to the security office in Whitehead Hall
and the shift changes. Thirteen men
stand packed together in the 9' by 10'
office, exchanging radios and punching
the time clock.
After the shift changes, Officer Bill
Deese takes over the patrol car: He is
middle-aged and talks a lot about his
two sons in the Navy.
For what seems about the hundredth
time, he checks the Rodgers House,
Homewood House, and Wolman Hall.
By this time the concert has broken up
and a steady stream of cars leave the
campus. A few couples walk arm in arm
towards the dorms or their cars and the
campus begins to quiet down.
"Unit one to post one- come in
please."
"Post one here."
"Have you been Levering yet?"
"Yeah, everything's quiet."
"O.K. Donny. 10-4."
The security people check the
Levering Cafeteria often because of the
food machines, according to Deese. All
doors, except the front, are locked and
checked by the watchmen on every
round.
Bush-Whacking
Another activity of the campus patrol
is bush-whacking parkers on San Martin
Drive with the car's powerful

searchlight. Tonight the activity is
limited and Deese manages flush out
only one couple with very steamed up
windows.
"Unit one, is that you on the grass
in front of the dorms?"
"No it isn't."
"O.K. 10-4."
At 1:30 am the campus is enveloped
in silence and only a few cars can be
seen leaving through the gate in front of
the library. The cold has moved in and
the few people on Charles Street move
quickly toward the warmth of their
homes and beds. Deese is checking the
computer center in Garland Hall, the
lights shining down the sides making it
stand out under the crystal clear, starry
sky.
Lights remain on in some of the
campus buildings where the janitors are
hard at work mopping the floors and
washing the blackboards covered with
white dust.
Moving slowly around the perimeter
of campus, Deese stops to put up
barricades for the football game the
next day. He moves quickly in the cold,
wearing only a sweater. When he gets
back in the car he seems refreshed and
wide awake, despite the fact that it is
three o'clock in the morning. Moving
away from the Athletic Center the wind
blows hundreds of leaves against the
fence surrounding the practice field as
Deese begins another set of rounds.
